subject: RE: [junit] TestCase question
msgSnippet: If out and in are a Collection of outs and ins, this seems like a very simple means of testing indeed. The reason I say if above is the out.size(i)
messageBody:
If out and in are a Collection of outs and ins, this seems like a very
simple means of testing indeed.

The reason I say "if" above is the "out.size(i)" statement in your for loop.
It's probably just a typo, but I'll play the part of the dummy and ask if
that was really what you meant. Was that really what you meant? :)

-jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Nagy Andrea [mailto:andrea.nagy@...]
> Sent: Friday, October 05, 2001 3:31 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] TestCase question
>
>
> Hi All!
>
> We are trying to set up JUnit for functional testing in
> our project.
>
> Could you suggest some solutions for the following
> problem or refer
> me to some earlier postings.
>
> I would like to do the following:
> I have a function that I want to call with different parameters.
> How is it possible to get the result of each run separately
>
> 1.
> testXX(){
>
> out1=myFunction(in1);
> assertEquals("diff",expectedout1, out1);
> }
> 2.
> And I have a list of theses in1 and expectedout1 things.
>
> how could I combine both these features into a testcase?
> Does it make sense at all?
>
>
> All I could imagine was the following thing, but it seems to
> contradict the paradigm to keep your tests simple and small.
>
> testXX(){
> for (i=0;i< out.size(i);i++){
> out[i]=myFunction(in[i]);
> assertEquals("diff",expectedout[i], out[i]);
> }
> }
>
> Any comments will be much appretiated.
> Nagy Andrea
